category.name: 1001 Most Useful Spanish Words - La Familia
1001 Most Useful Spanish Words - Los días de la semana
1001 Most Useful Spanish Words - Los meses del año
1001 Most Useful Spanish Words - Las estaciones

item.A:
really
De veras, yo no sé nada. Really, I don't know anything.

to be right
Él cree que siempre tiene razón. He thinks he's always right.
on, upon ex. al ver lo que pasaba, decidemos salir. Upon seeing what was happening, we decided to leave.

item.Q: aquel m. (aquella f.; aquellos m. pl.; aquellas f. pl.)

item.A: to suffice, be enough Ex. Ya basta. No quiero más. That's enough. I don't want anymore.
to fit in, to be room for
change, exchange ex. Perdone, pero no tengo cambio. Forgive me, but I have no change.
to get married Se casó con una muchacha mucho más joven que él. He married a girl much younger than he.
(wine) glass, drink Vamos a tomar una copa. Lets have a drink

to eat breakfast
¿Dónde desayunamos hot? Where shall we have breakfast today?

to say goodbye
Siempre lloro cuando nos depedimos. I always cry when we say goodbye.

To awaken, wake up
¿Queiren despartarme a las siete? Will you wake me at seven?

item.Q: el (m: (la f. los m. pl; las f. pl)

item.A: to be mistaken, to be wrong

item.Q: este (m.) (esta f.; estos m. pl.; estas f. pl.; esto [neuter pronoun])

item.A:
front (political, military)
Perdieron la guerra en el frente del este. They lost the war on the eastern front.

blow, knock
Fue como un golpe a la cabeza. It was like a blow to the head.

to enjoy
Gozan de buena salud. They're enjoying good health.

going, leaving
Un billete de ida y buelta, por favor. A round trip ticket please.

to sware
Juran que no lo robaron. They sware that they didn't steal it.

to wash(oneself)
¿Dónde podemos lavar la ropa? Where can we wash our clothes?

to him, to her, to you
Le hablo como amigo. I'm speaking to you as a friend.

to get up, stand up
Levántese, por favor, y hable en voz alta. Stand up, please, and speak in a loud voice.

it, him, you
No lo he visto todavía. I haven't seen him yet.

to call, be called
Se llama Francisco, pero todo el mundo le llama Paco. His name is Fransico, but everyone calls him Paco.

to put (in)
No sé done metí mi cartera. I don't know where I put my wallet.

while
Ella salió con el grupo mientras que yo descansaba. She went out with the group while I was resting.

mine
Esta maletas no son mías. These suitcases aren't mine.

(to) us
Nos llamaron y nos invitaron a la fiesta. They called us and invited us to the party.

work
Sus mejores obras están en este museo. His best works are in this museum.

to seem
Parece que no vienen. It seems that they're not coming.

worse, worst
¿Cómo se siente usted, mejor o peor? How do you feel, better or worse?

to worry
No se preocupe por eso. Don't worry about that.

to take off (clothing)
Se quitaron los zapatos antes de entrar. They took off their shoes before entering.
to return, come back, go back

suddenly
De repente apareció el niño. Suddenly, the child appeared.

cold (respiratory)
Tengo un resfriado contagioso. I have a contagious cold.

himself, herself, yourself, themselves, yourselves, oneself, one another
No se ven mucho pero se escriben todos los días. They don't see each other often but they write to each other every day.

if, whether
No sé si vienen con nosotros. I don't know if they're coming with us.

following, next
Primero visitamos el palacio, y el día siguiente fuimos al museo. First we visited the palace, and the next day we went to the museum.

such
Nunca hemos vito tal cosa. We've never seen such a thing.
¿Qué tal? How are things? How are you?

time (occasion)
Una vez no basta. Once isn't enough.

already
Ya lo sabíamos antes de leer la noticia en el periódico. We already knew it before reading the item in the newspaper.

item.A: dish of rice, meat, chicken, and shellfish
